answers.explanation: There is mild pallor of the right optic disc. Otherwise, the fundus examination was normal.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the abnormality in the fundus photographs above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
A Humphrey visual field (24-2) was subsequently performed and showed generalized depression of her visual field in the right eye.  

![](/content/media/neuro16-2.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro16-3.webp)

![](/content/media/neuro16-4.webp)

OCT RNFL was performed and shown above. Which abnormality is seen?

answers.answerText: A. Cupping of the left optic disc
B. Vitreopapillary traction of the right optic disc

answers.explanation:
The RNFL in the right eye is overall thinner compared to the left. This can be seen on inspection of the RNFL thickness map, deviation map and TSNIT plots. Even though the overall thickness of 84um is green and “considered” normal, the clear asymmetry suggests that this is abnormal for this patient.

![](/content/media/neuro16-5.webp)

Additionally, there is also thinning on the ganglion cell analysis in the right eye (shown below). This can be seen in the thickness map, deviation map and overall thickness. The temporal portion of the macula appears to be more affected than the nasal portion.

![](/content/media/neuro16-6.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Given the patient’s history and OCT findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Given the gradual course of her vision loss, the normal intraocular pressures, and the asymmetrical nature of the optic neuropathy with thinning of the RNFL and GCC in the affected eye, the most likely cause was a compressive optic neuropathy. An MRI brain was performed which showed an anterior clinoid meningioma with compression of the right optic nerve. 

![](/content/media/neuro16-7.webp)

MRI T1 post contrast (left) and T2 (right) show an enhancing mass arising from the right anterior clinoid compressing the right optic nerve. This was most consistent with a meningioma.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following factors is the most reliable predictor for visual recovery after surgery in cases of compressive optic neuropathy?

answers.answerText: A. Pre-operative RNFL and GCC thickness
answers.explanation: RNFL and macular GCC have been found to highly correlate with visual function in patients with compressive optic neuropathies. Preoperative RNFL and macular GCC thickness have emerged as the most reliable and consistent prognostic factors for visual recovery after surgery. Patients with an otherwise normal neuroophthalmic examination, including automated perimetry, may have macular GCC or RNFL thinning as the only manifestation of compression, enabling compressive optic neuropathies to be diagnosed at an earlier stage and managed accordingly.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What is the prognosis for this patient’s visual recovery post-decompressive surgery?

answers.answerText: A. No recovery is expected given the size of the compressive lesion
B. The patient should recover a substantial amount of vision with timely surgery
answers.explanation:
Although there is asymmetry between the OCT RNFL thicknesses in both eyes, the patient still has not had significant atrophy (the mean thickness pre-op was 84um). When the optic nerve is examined, there was only mild temporal pallor and the remainder of the optic nerve appeared healthy. This patient recovered a visual acuity of 20/30 OD and her post-operative visual field at 6 months is shown below. 

![](/content/media/neuro16-8.webp)

answers.answerText: C. Worse vision is expected post-op and the goal of surgery is to protect the fellow eye
D. We cannot prognosticate given the large size of the mass

questions.title: Question 6
questions.text: What OCT RNFL changes are expected post-decompressive surgery?

answers.answerText: A. There will be an increase in the pre-operative RNFL thickness
B. There will be a decrease in the pre-operative RNFL thickness
C. There will be no change in the pre-operative RNFL thickness
answers.explanation:
Although the visual field and visual acuity are expected to improve post-decompressive surgery, the OCT RNFL and optic nerve structure usually do not change. This is shown in the OCT RNFL printouts below. 

![](/content/media/neuro16-9.webp)

questions.title: Question 7
questions.text: Which of the following OCT findings can aid in differentiating cases of compressive optic neuropathy from glaucoma?

answers.answerText: A. Enlargement of optic nerve cup
C. Proportionally more thinning of nasal and temporal RNFL
answers.explanation: Cases of compressive optic neuropathy and open-angle glaucoma discs can present with enlargement of the optic cup and thinning of the RNFL. However, compressive optic neuropathy discs have proportionally more thinning nasally and temporally compared with open-angle glaucoma discs.

title: Case 16
description: 64F presenting with gradual, painless vision loss OD
patientPresentation:
**Contributor:** Marko Tien (University of British Columbia Medical Student)

A 64-year-old woman was referred to an ophthalmology clinic for gradual, painless vision loss in the right eye over the last two months. She denied any neurological symptoms and review of systems was otherwise unremarkable. She has a history of hypertension that was controlled on medication. On presentation, her visual acuity was 20/320 OD and 20/25 OS. She had normal intraocular pressures. She had a right RAPD. Fundus examination was performed and shown below:
